posts.name: Henrique de Sousa Neves
posts.cooked: Hello everyone, we are trying to set up the PID on the swerve. Do you have any tips to help us be more precise?

posts.name: dasevo
posts.cooked:
What does “more precise” mean for you? Some teams strive for general accuracy of ± inch or two, other go for full precision.

To get the first, using only P-control should work just fine. For steering, you don’t need much tuning at all, just keep ramping up the kP parameter until the modules turn where you need them to be. If they start oscilating or overshooting, you need to lower the kP. For driving, this is a bit harder as both Pathplanner and the motors themselves have a PID controller. If you keep the PathPlanner (assuming you use it) at the “default” 5.0, you should be able to tune your motor PID by telling the robot to drive for example 1m forwards and backwards. Keep ramping up the kP until the robot drives full meter forwards AND returns to the spot, where it started from.

To achieve better precision, I would suggest using SysID (we haven’t done this just yet ourselves as the kP control was just fine)

link_counts.title: System Identification — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

posts.name: Henrique de Sousa Neves
posts.cooked: Another issue we are facing is that the PathPlanner is not retrieving the PID values or the offsets. How can we check if it is pulling these values, and how can we resolve this problem? (2024 version)

posts.name: dasevo
posts.cooked:
What exactly do you mean by offset? The starting position of the robot or the initial steering offsets of the modules themselves?

The first thing you should be able to do is to try to drive manually in tele-op. If your steering works fine in tele-op, then driving in auto shouldn’t be an issue. I’ll try to refer to some of the things through our code . Please note that we are using an unusual setup with NEO for steering and Falcon 500 for driving. Also the code on Github is currently non-functional as we forgot to push the current working version.

If you are using an absolute encoder on your modules and/or different motors, your code will look different but this is the base code that has worked for us for the past three years. If you are able to share your code, I might be able to help you more than giving vague ideas and a code that is likely very different to yours.

posts.name: Henrique de Sousa Neves
posts.cooked: Thank you, and  What is the best maximum speed to use in autonomous mode?

posts.name: dasevo
posts.cooked: The speed isn’t the main limiting factor, especially this year. We have max auto speed set to 5m/s with L3+ modules, but I doubt that we ever hit this speed. You want to focus on acceleration instead. The higher the acceleration, the quicker you’ll be able to hit the top speed. But if the acceleration is too high, your wheels will start losing traction or your whole robot will tip over. We’re running a pretty conservative 2.5 m/s^2 at the moment but we’ll try bringing this up over the weekend.

posts.name: Johnathon
posts.cooked: If you are using motors that run ctre software they released 2025 code for using sysID to to tune motors. My team just tried them out but not entirely sure on its results yet.

posts.name: Henrique de Sousa Neves
posts.cooked: We’re utilizing the 2024 version, but how does this sysID function? What is it and what does it do?

posts.name: Johnathon
posts.cooked: Essentially it lets you create routines for your mechanisms to run. While it runs these routines it logs the motor voltage, position, and velocity of the motors on the mechanism. You can feed this log into the sysID software that came with the game tools and it should give you feed forward values that move the mechanism optimally. I’ve been having difficulty with it for mechanisms other than drive though.
